title: Exiting multiple loops
question: Which of these statements about multiple loops are true?
hint: Exiting multiple loops is done by using break with a loop label.

correct.answer: A loop inside a loop is called a nested loop.
Using break by itself exits the current loop only.
You can exit more than one loop at a time.
You can break out of a labeled loop whenever you need.
You can embed one loop inside another.

wrong.answer: You may have only one labeled loop.
wrong.reason: You may have as many labeled loops as you need.

wrong.answer: Nesting can only be used with for loops.
wrong.reason: You can nest while loops too, if you want.
They are written as loopName: followed by your regular loop code.

wrong.answer: You can exit up to two loops at a time.
wrong.reason: You can exit more loops than that if you need to, although it's possible your code is a little dubious at that point.

wrong.answer: You can only break out of loops inside a condition.
wrong.reason: You can break out of loops outside of conditions just fine.

wrong.answer: You can write break 3 to break out of two loops.
wrong.reason: We use names rather than numbers for breaking out of a specific loops.
